user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_set_nodelay_state_:
```c
bool
MHD_connection_set_nodelay_state_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                                   bool nodelay_state)
{
#ifdef TCP_NODELAY
  const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ off_val = 0;
  const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ on_val = 1;
  int err_code;

  if (_MHD_YES == connection->is_nonip)
    return false;

  if (0 == setsockopt (connection->socket_fd,
                       IPPROTO_TCP,
                       TCP_NODELAY,
                       (const void *) (nodelay_state ? &on_val : &off_val),
                       sizeof (off_val)))
  {
    connection->sk_nodelay = nodelay_state;
    return true;
  }

  err_code = MHD_socket_get_error_ ();
  if (MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_EINVAL_) ||
      MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_ENOPROTOOPT_) ||
      MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_ (err_code, MHD_SCKT_ENOTSOCK_))
  {
    if (_MHD_UNKNOWN == connection->is_nonip)
      connection->is_nonip = _MHD_YES;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    else
    {
      MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
                _ ("Setting %s option to %s state failed "
                   "for TCP/IP socket %d: %s\n"),
                "TCP_NODELAY",
                nodelay_state ? _ ("ON") : _ ("OFF"),
                (int) connection->socket_fd,
                MHD_socket_strerr_ (err_code));
    }
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
  }
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  else
  {
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("Setting %s option to %s state failed: %s\n"),
              "TCP_NODELAY",
              nodelay_state ? _ ("ON") : _ ("OFF"),
              MHD_socket_strerr_ (err_code));
  }
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */

#else  /* ! TCP_NODELAY */
  (void) connection; (void) nodelay_state; /* Mute compiler warnings */
#endif /* ! TCP_NODELAY */
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#else  /* ! TCP_NODELAY */
  (void) connection; (void) nodelay_state; /* Mute compiler warnings */
#endif /* ! TCP_NODELAY */
explanation: I flagged all points where control flow may prematurely exit or where conditional compilation produces code that may be absent/unused in a particular build: the early return when connection->is_nonip is _MHD_YES, the immediate return on successful setsockopt, the final return at function end, the TCP_NODELAY #else branch that only exists when the feature is not available, and the nested if/else under the error-check block combined with the HAVE_MESSAGES conditional. These locations are the only places in the function that create potential unreachable-code concerns (either by early returns or by code present/absent depending on macros). Other fragments (variable declarations, the normal error logging block compiled when HAVE_MESSAGES is set, the call to MHD_socket_get_error_(), the assignment to connection->is_nonip, and the surrounding preprocessor directives themselves) are reachable in at least one compilation/configuration or at runtime along some path, so they do not indicate unreachable code and do not need further investigation for MISRA Rule 2.1 in this function.
